sample-isolation-and-treatment_sample_is: A hydrothermal fluid sample (8.5 L) was obtained during Dive No. 793 (12Â° 57. 172′ N, 143Â° 37. 167′ E, water depth 2,850 m, fluid temperature ∼106Â°C, Fryer site) of the YK03-09 cruise conducted in the Mariana Trough in 2003, employing ÂShinkai 6500 (6K)Â from the ÂYokosukaÂ of the Japan Marine Science and Technology Center (currently, Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology) into gamma-ray-sterilized polythene bags through impeller pumps. Possibility of entrainment of ambient seawater was not ruled out. Immediately after retrieval, 0.2-μm- and 0.1-μm-Sterivex filters (Millipore Corp., Bedford, MA, USA) were consecutively used to trap 0.2-μm-passable microorganisms (Miyoshi et al. 2005), and frozen onboard at −20Â°C. The Teflon and Tygon tubes for filtration and the polypropylene bottles for sample storage were washed with HCl and autoclaved before use. The mixed genomic DNA of 0.2-μm-passable microorganisms used in this research is the same extracted DNA (0.69 μg) as that used in the previous PCR clone library analysis of collaborative authors, Naganuma et al. (2007). Multiple displacement amplification (MDA), with phi29 DNA polymerase, was used to obtain a sufficient (>10 μg) DNA sample for 454 pyrosequencing.
sequences_sequences_filtered: We obtained 21.3 μg of DNA by amplification from 10 ng of bulk DNA and pyrosequenced the MDA product to produce 323,700 reads. Of these, 121,052 (37.4%) of all reads were removed in line with reports on systematic artifacts associated with pyrosequencing technology (Gomez-Alvarez et al. 2009).
